questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of multiple episodes of coughing up blood over the past 2 hours. He says that he has coughed up approximately half a cup of bright-red blood each time. He has had progressively worsening shortness of breath on exertion and a productive cough with occasionally blood-tinged sputum for the past 6 months. He has a history of hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He drinks 2 to 3 beers every evening. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. His medications include amlodipine, tiotropium, and an albuterol inhaler as needed. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 97/63 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. He appears anxious and cachectic. Auscultation of the lungs shows decreased breath sounds bilaterally. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. During the examination, the patient coughs up copious amounts of blood. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8800/mm3, and platelet count is 160,000/mm3. His coagulation parameters are within normal limits. Serum studies and urinalysis show no abnormalities. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. An x-ray of the chest shows hyperinflation of the lung fields and a 2-cm nodule in the right lower lobe. In addition to placing the patient in the right lateral decubitus position, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Radionuclide scanning with tagged red blood cells has been successfully used to identify the source of bleeding in individual cases of hemoptysis. However, this technique will only work if there is severe bleeding and may not be accurate if blood pools within the lung. For these reasons, it is not generally recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the chest is indicated in patients with a new lesion detected on chest x-ray. CT scan may also be used to identify the bleeding site in patients with hemoptysis and should be performed within the first 12–24 hours of symptom manifestation. However, in this patient with active bleeding and vital signs indicating hemodynamic compromise, another management modality should be performed first.

C) INCORRECT:

Upper endoscopy is indicated in the evaluation of patients with hematemesis. While it can sometimes be difficult to distinguish between hemoptysis and hematemesis, this patient's history of progressive shortness of breath with a cough productive of blood-tinged sputum and a pulmonary nodule on chest x-ray are highly suggestive of hemoptysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgery should be considered in patients with unilateral bleeding not controllable by first-line and second-line treatments. However, no attempts to control this patient's hemoptysis with less invasive treatment options have been made yet. Additionally, lung resection, particularly in patients with active pulmonary bleeding, is associated with high morbidity and mortality and first requires evaluation of the patient's ability to undergo surgery. This patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which may disqualify him for surgery.

E) INCORRECT:

Arteriography may be used to identify a site of intrapulmonary hemorrhage and stop the bleeding via embolization. While this treatment option is indicated in patients with persistent hemoptysis after first-line treatment has failed, no other hemostatic measures have been attempted in this patient yet.

F) CORRECT:

Initial steps in the management of massive life-threatening hemoptysis involve the correct positioning of the patient (with the bleeding lung in the dependent position), airway protection, and cardiovascular support. After the patient has been stabilized, bronchoscopy is indicated to identify the source of bleeding as well as to stop the bleeding (e.g., via balloon tamponade, iced saline lavage, topical epinephrine, or laser therapy). If bleeding cannot be controlled by bronchoscopy, arteriography with embolization or surgery should be attempted. In patients with signs of coagulopathy, or those taking anticoagulants, transfusion of blood products or administration of reversal agents may be warranted.

In a patient with a significant smoking history, an x-ray finding of a pulmonary nodule in combination with pulmonary symptoms (progressive shortness of breath and cough productive of blood-tinged sputum) suggests pulmonary hemorrhage due to bronchogenic carcinoma.
questions.hint: This patient presents with massive hemoptysis and a pulmonary nodule on x-ray. After securing his airway and cardiovascular function, the source of bleeding should be located.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old man with a history of diffuse arthralgias, rash, and intermittent shortness of breath is admitted to the intensive care unit with severe hypoxemia that developed rapidly during the previous week. The patient is subsequently intubated. His wife reports that during the week before admission, he had a persistent cough that produced blood-tinged sputum, which he previously had never experienced.
The patient has had chronic joint pain and swelling for several years and has treated himself with ibuprofen as needed. Laboratory testing documents a hematocrit of 32.0% (reference range, 41.0–53.0). A postintubation chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate to perform next for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The clinical picture of possible rheumatologic disease and associated hypoxemic respiratory failure with blood-tinged sputum, anemia, and diffuse bilateral opacities on imaging should raise concern for diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH). However, the symptoms of this condition are nonspecific, and hemoptysis can be absent in one-third of patients. DAH occurs when erythrocytes accumulate in the alveolar spaces. Injury to the alveolar capillaries can be secondary to local injury (e.g., inhalations) or systemic illness (e.g., vasculitis or connective-tissue disease). The diagnostic test of choice for DAH is sequential bronchoalveolar lavages of a lung segment, which can reveal elevated erythrocyte counts. Subsequent testing should be directed at determining the cause of DAH (e.g., toxicology screen, antinuclear antibody testing).

Key learning point: The most appropriate way to diagnose diffuse alveolar hemorrhage is sequential bronchoalveolar lavages of the same lung region to identify elevated erythrocyte counts.

B) INCORRECT:

Haptoglobin levels are low in patients with hemolysis but would not necessarily be affected in DAH.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary angiography is the gold-standard test to diagnose acute pulmonary embolism. Ventilation-perfusion scan can also be used to diagnose acute or chronic pulmonary embolism.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary angiography is the gold-standard test to diagnose acute pulmonary embolism. Ventilation-perfusion scan can also be used to diagnose acute or chronic pulmonary embolism.

E) INCORRECT:

The direct Coombs test is used to detect autoimmune hemolytic anemia but would not be helpful in diagnosing DAH.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old woman with a history of bronchiectasis is admitted to the hospital with shortness of breath and a 2-day history of coughing up bloody sputum. She reports no fevers, night sweats, weight loss, or lymphadenopathy. She has never smoked, traveled abroad, or been homeless or incarcerated.
She has an oxygen saturation of 89% while breathing ambient air and 92% while receiving 2 liters of supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula. Her lung examination reveals left basilar crackles without wheezes. She has a regular heart rate and rhythm; no jugular venous distention; no cervical, axillary, or inguinal lymphadenopathy; no evidence of clubbing; and no lower-extremity edema.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A chest radiograph obtained on admission shows chronic changes consistent with her known bronchiectasis but no acute process. A chest CT reveals chronic bilateral bronchiectasis with new ground-glass opacities in the left lower lobe. Ceftriaxone and azithromycin are initiated.
Six hours after admission to the hospital, the patient coughs up approximately 300 mL of bright-red blood and clots. She is hemodynamically stable with a blood pressure of 114/68 mm Hg, a heart rate of 88 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 91% while receiving 2 liters of supplemental oxygen. Her physical examination is unchanged.
A repeat chest radiograph now shows a hazy opacity in the left lower lobe. The hemoglobin concentration, platelet count, renal function, prothrombin time, international normalized ratio, and partial thromboplastin time are all within normal limits.
In addition to positioning the patient with the affected side down, what is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Observation of respiratory status and serial hemoglobin levels
Thoracic surgery consultation for video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery
Observation of respiratory status and sputum analysis for acid-fast stain

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has massive hemoptysis, a medical emergency that requires prompt evaluation. There are varying definitions of “massive” hemoptysis, ranging from 200 mL to 1000 mL of blood produced in 24 hours or more than 100 mL in a single setting. Once the diagnosis is recognized, the patient needs emergency evaluation to help localize the site of bleeding and attempt hemostasis. The most common causes of hemoptysis are bronchiectasis, tuberculosis and other infections, malignancy, autoimmune diseases, arteriovenous malformations, and medications (particularly chemotherapy).

Initial management of massive hemoptysis should focus on protecting the airway and positioning the patient with the suspected bleeding side down to help minimize the amount of blood spilling over into the nonaffected lung. In this patient, the left lateral recumbent position is most appropriate because of the CT changes in the left lower lobe, which raise concern for bleeding localized to that lobe.

The next steps in management should focus on efforts to localize the source of bleeding, with priority placed on those interventions that can also serve as treatment. Flexible bronchoscopy can sometimes be useful in helping to localize the site of minor bleeding and is rapidly available at the bedside in most intensive care units; with massive hemoptysis, locating a specific site of bleeding is usually difficult because blood will often be seen throughout the respiratory tree. Rigid bronchoscopy is generally performed in an operating room or procedure suite, so it rarely happens quickly enough to be useful for massive hemoptysis. More importantly, bronchoscopy offers little in the way of therapeutic intervention. Patients with bronchiectasis who present with massive hemoptysis are at risk for hemorrhage from a bronchial artery, a source that would not be amenable to bronchoscopic intervention. Current guidelines therefore give mixed guidance on flexible bronchoscopy in this setting, and no guidelines recommend rigid bronchoscopy.

In this case, the patient’s chest CT reveals new ground-glass opacities in the left lower lobe suggestive of hemorrhage, which is adequate localization to proceed with angiography. Angiography by interventional radiology is therefore preferable, as it would be able to both localize the source of bleeding and treat it with arterial embolization.

Key learning point: In a patient with chronic bronchiectasis who presents with massive hemoptysis, stable vital signs, and localized changes on imaging, the most important initial management is to position the patient with the affected side down and obtain emergency angiography by interventional radiology.

B) INCORRECT:

Obtaining serial hemoglobin levels and monitoring this patient’s respiratory status would be inappropriate because she has massive hemoptysis. This is a medical emergency and warrants interventions that can treat the source of bleeding.

C) INCORRECT:

Thoracic surgery consultation can be considered for massive hemoptysis that is not controllable with bronchoscopy or embolization.

D) INCORRECT:

Flexible bronchoscopy can sometimes be useful in helping to localize the site of minor bleeding and is rapidly available at the bedside in most intensive care units; with massive hemoptysis, locating a specific site of bleeding is usually difficult because blood will often be seen throughout the respiratory tree. Rigid bronchoscopy is generally performed in an operating room or procedure suite, so it rarely happens quickly enough to be useful for massive hemoptysis. More importantly, bronchoscopy offers little in the way of therapeutic intervention. Patients with bronchiectasis who present with massive hemoptysis are at risk for hemorrhage from a bronchial artery, a source that would not be amenable to bronchoscopic intervention. Current guidelines therefore give mixed guidance on flexible bronchoscopy in this setting, and no guidelines recommend rigid bronchoscopy.

E) INCORRECT:

Sending a sputum culture for acid-fast staining and monitoring respiratory status would be inappropriate because of the amount of hemoptysis noted. Tuberculosis is a common cause of hemoptysis and should be considered in the evaluation despite the absence of obvious risk factors, but initial management should focus on interventions that can identify and control the source of bleeding.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 11-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother after she expectorated roughly half a teaspoon of blood-tinged sputum last night and again this morning. In both instances, the sputum was pinkish-red and frothy in appearance. She has been coughing for the past week but has had no fever, wheezing, trauma, choking, nausea, or vomiting. She has no history of nosebleeds. Her growth and development have been normal, and she has never been hospitalized.
In the emergency department, the patient has another witnessed episode of expectorating a small amount of bright-red, frothy material. She has a temperature of 36.4°C, a heart rate of 115 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 99/66 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air. Her cardiac examination demonstrates a quiet precordium, normal S1 and S2, no murmur, and brisk capillary refill. She has symmetric 2+ peripheral pulses. Her respiratory examination is notable for no increased work of breathing and faint crackles bilaterally at the bases without wheezes or rhonchi. Her oropharynx and nasopharynx are clear. She has no clubbing. The remainder of the examination is normal.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. The results of a complete blood count with differential are as follows:

A chest radiograph shows small bilateral parenchymal and alveolar opacities.
Which one of the following tests should be performed next in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lung biopsy is used in the diagnosis of a wide range of conditions including neoplasms, transplant-mediated rejection, and idiopathic pulmonary hypertension, all of which can cause hemoptysis but would not be assessed first in the diagnostic workup.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemoptysis is a complication of cystic fibrosis that results from bronchiectasis. However, cystic fibrosis is unlikely to manifest with hemoptysis alone in a previously healthy child who has been growing well. As such, a sweat test would be of low yield.

C) INCORRECT:

Based on the appearance of the sputum in this patient, and given that she has no history of vomiting, the source is not likely to be gastrointestinal. She has no history of nosebleeds, and her oropharynx and nasopharynx are clear. Hence, it is likely that her episodes represent true hemoptysis; esophagogastroduodenoscopy would not be the most high-yield next step in evaluation.

D) CORRECT:

Hemoptysis (the expectoration of blood or blood-tinged sputum from the respiratory tract) is a rare diagnosis in children and may even go unnoticed, as children tend to swallow their sputum. The differential diagnosis of hemoptysis is broad and includes infections (such as pneumonia or tuberculosis), cystic fibrosis, congenital heart disease, foreign-body aspiration, pulmonary hemosiderosis, and pulmonary neoplasm.

Evaluation of hemoptysis should be done systematically. First, providers should determine if the patient is medically stable. This patient is alert and appears well, with normal vital signs for her age, except for tachycardia likely due to anemia. Next, a thorough history should be obtained. The provider should take care in distinguishing hemoptysis from hematemesis, as the two are often confounded in children. In hemoptysis, the expectorated blood is usually bright red and often has a frothy appearance. In contrast, the expectorated blood in hematemesis may be darker red or brown and often follows a period of emesis or retching; it is sometimes described as appearing like coffee grounds.

A complete blood count should be obtained in cases in which hemoptysis is suspected, both to assess the hemoglobin level and to identify signs of infection. A chest radiograph should be obtained as well, to rule out infection and to look for signs of foreign-body aspiration, such as unilateral air trapping. However, it is important to know that the chest radiograph is normal in up to one-third of patients with hemoptysis. When a patient has significant bleeding, abnormalities on chest radiograph, or a low hemoglobin level, as in this case, bronchoscopy should be performed to identify the source of the bleeding.

Key learning point: Three key laboratory and imaging studies used to evaluate a patient with hemoptysis are complete blood count with differential, chest radiography, and bronchoscopy.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemoptysis is a complication of cystic fibrosis that results from bronchiectasis. It may also occur in the context of congenital heart disease due to the presence of collateral vessels in the lungs or pulmonary hypertension. However, cystic fibrosis and congenital heart disease are unlikely to manifest with hemoptysis alone in a previously healthy child who has been growing well. As such, an echocardiogram would be of low yield.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of cavitary tuberculosis presents with sudden onset of blood-streaked sputum that has progressively worsened over the past 3 hours. He feels short of breath and reports expectorating approximately 200 mL of bright red blood during this time. Vital signs are BP, 100/65; P, 118; R, 22; oxygen saturation, 94% on room air. Physical examination shows decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion over the right upper lobe. The patient appears anxious and reports mild shortness of breath. What is the most appropriate initial management step?

choices.text: Position patient with right side down
Obtain urgent CT chest with contrast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient likely has massive hemoptysis based on expectorating > 100 mL of blood, shortness of breath, and tachycardia. The initial priority is lung isolation by positioning the patient in lateral decubitus with the bleeding side down. This positioning prevents blood from flooding the nonbleeding lung and maintains gas exchange through gravity.

B) INCORRECT:

Tranexamic acid is a useful hemostatic agent in massive hemoptysis and may reduce mortality and length of hospital stay. However, basic positioning to protect the functioning lung takes immediate priority before pharmacological interventions.

C) INCORRECT:

Flexible bronchoscopy is the first-line modality for hemostasis in massive hemoptysis and is typically required since basic measures rarely control bleeding. However, immediate positioning to protect the functioning lung comes first.

D) INCORRECT:

Endotracheal intubation with a large endotracheal tube (internal diameter ≥ 8.5 mm) is indicated when signs of airway compromise are present in massive hemoptysis. However, this patient currently maintains adequate oxygen saturation and gas exchange, making immediate positioning to prevent aspiration of blood into the nonbleeding lung the more urgent priority.

E) INCORRECT:

CT chest with contrast is appropriate to localize bleeding in hemodynamically stable patients with massive hemoptysis. However, immediate stabilization measures must be performed first to prevent airway compromise and maintain gas exchange.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and bronchiectasis presents with acute hemoptysis. He has expectorated approximately 150 mL of bright red blood over 30 minutes. Initial vital signs are BP, 94/58; P, 120; R, 28; and oxygen saturation, 86% on room air. Physical examination shows an anxious patient with moderate respiratory distress and decreased breath sounds on the right side with coarse crackles. Large-bore IV access is established, fluid resuscitation is initiated, emergency blood transfusion is ordered,  and supplemental oxygen is started via face mask. What is the most appropriate immediate next step in management?

choices.text: Lateral decubitus positioning with right side down

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is valuable for localizing bleeding sources but is only appropriate in stable patients. Another immediate management step is more appropriate for this unstable patient with massive hemoptysis.

B) INCORRECT:

Bronchial artery embolization is an important definitive treatment for massive hemoptysis, but it can only be considered once the patient has been stabilized. Another immediate step in management is more appropriate for this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Flexible bronchoscopy is the first-line modality for bronchoscopic hemostasis in massive hemoptysis, but another stabilization measure should be implemented first in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – Lateral decubitus positioning with the bleeding side down is the most appropriate immediate next step in management. This positioning uses gravity to prevent blood from flooding the nonbleeding lung and protects the functioning lung from aspiration, which is critical for maintaining gas exchange in massive hemoptysis.

E) INCORRECT:

Intubation and mechanical ventilation may be necessary for this patient's stabilization and as a preparation for emergency bronchoscopy, especially if he develops signs of airway compromise or remains unstable following initial measures, but another immediate step in management should be implemented first.
